citeinfo.title: Cape Cod National Seashore Vegetation Mapping Project - Spatial Vegetation Data

citeinfo.origin: L.A. Sneddon, R.E. Zaremba, and M. Adams
citeinfo.title: Vegetation Classification and Mapping at Cape Cod National Seashore, Massachusetts

descript.abstract: Vegetation within the Cape Cod N.S. based on 2001 true color aerial images with reference to 2000 color IR aerial photos
descript.purpose: To characterize vegetation communities using the U.S. National Vegetation Classification Standard (2007) and to provide a comprehensive vegetation coverage for Cape Cod N.S.
descript.supplinf: The shapefile was imported into a geodatabase by the USGS/CSS/Core Science Analytics and Synthesis

spdom.descgeog: Cape Cod National Seashore and environs

National Park System Unit Code Thesaurus

browse.browsed: Vegetation map; low resolution for web browsing.

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.3000

attracc.attraccr: Accuracy assessed by Natureserve. Aggregated attributes achieve a minimum accuracy of 80% (field name: AGGREG_NAME).

horizpa.horizpar: Positional accuracy based on MASS GIS 2001 DOQS (http://www.mass.gov/mgis/colororthos2001.htm) with estimated horzontal accuracy of 1-2 meters.

citeinfo.title: Cape Cod National Seashore Color Infrared Orthorectified Photomosaics, 2000
citeinfo.othercit: A set of five orthorectified color infrared MrSID images of Cape Cod National Seashore: ntruro-mosaic5-7.sid, ntruro-mosaic-8-10.sid, nwwellf-mos-4-7.sid, pamet-mos-4-7.sid and PROV-mosaic11-14.sid. Produced from color infrared photos taken October 4, 2000 by James Sewall Company, Old Town, Maine. Orthorectification accomplished with IMAGINE Orthobase software to result in about 1-meter pixel resolution. This set of photomosaics was originally intended to be used for photo interpretation to produce a vegetation map of Cape Cod National Seashore. They were ultimately found to be unsatisfactory for the intended purpose due to color distortions and uneven horizontal accuracy, however, they were used to aid in land cover interpretation and for spatial reference of vegetation polygons based on Cape Cod Vegetation Classification categories (2004).

citeinfo.title: Cape Cod National Seashore True Color Orthorectified Photomosaics-developed from MassGIS tiles
citeinfo.othercit: A set of two orthorectified true color images of Cape Cod National Seashore developed from digital true color aerial images obtained from MassGIS: cape1.sid and cape2.sid. Keystone Aerial Surveys, Inc. of Philadelphia, PA flew the photography in April 2001. The source imagery was acquired with Leica RC-30 calibrated aerial mapping cameras at a flying height of approximately 5,000 meters (15,000 feet). The medium resolution true color images have a horizontal accuracy of +- 3 meters at the 95% confidence level at the nominal scale of 1:5,000.

srcinfo.srccontr: Aerial view of Cape Cod National Seashore

procstep.procdesc: Photo interpretation to delineate discrete vegetation and land use types by Donna Peterson, U. Mass, Amherst, Resource Mapping Project Office. Preliminary working classification system developed by U Mass. Photointerpreted polygons digitzed on screen at U. Mass using 2000 IR orthomosaics (created at URI using ERDAS orthobase) and 2001 true-color orthomosaics from MassGIS program. Tile edge topology and mismatched polygons across tiles corrected by CACO GIS office by referencing original photography. Cape Cod classification system and key developed from the U.S. National Vegetation Classification (2004; revised 2007) by Lesley Sneddon, Natureserve/Nature Conservancy. Working classification types crosswalked to NVCS by Steve Smith (NPS CACO). NVCS system field verified, data stored in PLOTS database. US National Vegetation Classification Standard (2007). Accuracy assessment and aggregation of types performed by Robert Zaremba and Leslie Sneddon to meet 80% minimum accuracy standard.
The shapefile was imported into a geodatabase by the USGS/CSS/Core Science Analytics and Synthesis.

distinfo.distliab:
The U.S. Geological Survey and the National Park Service shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein. These data and related graphics (if available) are not legal documents and are not intended to be used as such.
The information contained in these data is dynamic and may change over time. The data are not better than the original sources from which they were derived. It is the responsibility of the data user to use the data appropriately and consistent within the limitations of geospatial data in general and these data in particular. Any related graphics (if available) are intended to aid the data user in acquiring relevant data; it is not approriate to use the related graphics as data.
The U.S. Geological Survey and the National Park Service gives no warranty, expressed or implied, as to the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of these data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from an U.S. Geological Survey and National Park Service servers and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the utility of the data on another system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data. Mention of trade names or commercial products in this metadata report does not constitute endorsement or recommendation for use by the U. S. Department of the Interior, U. S. Geological Survey and National Park Service.
